title: Gary Numan to receive Q Awards' Innovation In Sound gong
text:
Gary Numan to receive Q Awards' Innovation In Sound gong Gary Numan to receive Q Awards' Innovation In Sound gong 
Press Association 2014 / / National Entertainment News Share 
Electronic music pioneer Gary Numan is set to receive the Innovation In Sound honour at this year’s Q Awards. 
The 57-year-old, who was one of the key players in the 80s synth-pop era, with hits including Are ‘Friends’ Electric? and Cars, will be handed the gong at the annual music event later this month. 
He follows in the footsteps of Jean Michel Jarre, who picked up the Innovation In Sound title in 2014. Others who have been honoured with the prize include Underworld, Mark Ronson, Sonic Youth, Massive Attack, Sigur Ros, The Prodigy and Muse. Jean Michel Jarre winning the award in 2014 (Joel Ryan/AP) 
Gary said: “To receive any award in music is an honour. But to receive the Q Innovation In Sound award is particularly special. 
“Sound is the most important aspect of making music to me, it’s why electronic music has been such an obsession. It allows you the opportunity to constantly create new and exciting sounds. I’m very grateful to Q for the award, and very proud.” 
Numan has been a true music pioneer since he first rose to prominence with his band, Tubeway Army. Gary Numan (Mark Allan/AP) 
His songs have been covered by Foo Fighters and Sugababes, and sampled by producers such as J Dilla and GZA, and his influence has resonated across pop, rock, industrial, electronica and hip-hop over the last three-and-a-half decades – all while he continues to make his own records. 
Three of his classic albums – Replicas, The Pleasure Principle and Telekon – are about to be reissued on vinyl and performed live in UK shows this month. 
Having taken place annually since 1990, the Q Awards – run by the monthly music magazine – will be hosted by Absolute Radio’s Christian O’Connell in 2015. 
Voting is open online for seven of the categories, with nominees including Florence + The Machine, Foals, Ed Sheeran, Noel Gallagher’s High Flying Birds, Blur, Everything Everything, Jamie XX, Muse, James Bay, Sam Smith, Kanye West, Taylor Swift, The Libertines, New Order and The Weeknd. 
Last year’s winners included Sam Smith, Ed Sheeran, Jamie XX, Kasabian, Pink Floyd and Culture Club. Share article 
The awards will take place on Monday October 19. Promoted Stories
